body:
<!-- This form is for bug reports and feature requests ONLY!

If you're looking for help check [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/kubernetes) and the [troubleshooting guide](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug-application-cluster/troubleshooting/).

If the matter is security related, please disclose it privately via https://kubernetes.io/security/.
-->

**Is this a BUG REPORT or FEATURE REQUEST?**:

> Uncomment only one, leave it on its own line:
>
/kind bug
> /kind feature


**What happened**:
In GCE env, AESGCM encryption of secrets by default generates a secret key with /dev/random instead of /dev/urandom
**What you expected to happen**:
On running cluster/kube-up.sh in GCE provider should create and initialize a cluster without any issue. However, I am seeing below error - 

error: error while parsing encryption provider configuration file "/etc/srv/kubernetes/encryption-provider-config.yml": error while creating cipher for named key key1: crypto/aes: invalid key size 8

This happens because sometime, /dev/random generates a key with smaller size than 32-byte. Replacing it with /dev/urandom fixes the issue as it consistently generates 32-byte secret key.

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:
1. Setup Kubernetes on Ubuntu xenial (16.04). 
2. make quick-release
3. Kick-off cluster/kube-up.sh with provider=gce

**Anything else we need to know?**:
No
**Environment**:
- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`): v1.12.0-alpha.1.41+c2536e2b0d6be6-dirty
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: GCE
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Ubuntu 16.04
- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`): Linux scspa0509399001 4.4.0-122-generic #146-Ubuntu SMP Mon Apr 23 15:34:04 UTC 2018 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
- Install tools: gce-sdk
- Others:

labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.
labels.name: kind/bug

title: Use of /dev/random generates secret key with invalid size in gce
